A Review of Dr. Howard A. Kelly's Book
“WALTER REED AND YELLOW FEVER”,
Third Edition,
The Horman, Remington Company, Publishers,
by
Colonel J. R. Kean, M.C.

Dr. Howard A. Kelly of Baltimore has brought out a third edition
of his notable work, “Walter Reed and Yellow Fever”. In it he has added
to his former narrative of the work of Reed and his assistants on the Yellow
Fever Commission biographical sketches of Surgeon General George M. Stern-
berg and Surgeon General William C. Gorgas, with brief mention of the more
recent work of Dr. Hideyo Noguchi of the Rockefeller Foundation. These
four, Sternberg, Reed, Gorgas and Noguchi he considers to have supplemented
each the work of the other and by their combined labors to have won “the
greatest battle ever fought for the health of the human race”. Of these,
all but the last have passed beyond the Veil, and so it is now possible to
view from approximately the historical standpoint the epic story of their
accomplishment and to estimate the relative value of their contributions
to the winning of the great battle. They have been placed in the order of
their appearance in the lists to combat that mysterious and mortal enemy
of mankind which had routed armies and ravaged cities and had so often
brought death and mourning into the homes of America. In this order let
us consider them and their contributions to the victory.

George Miller Sternberg was born in Otsego County, New York, in
1838, of an old Lutheran family of the Palatinate. He graduated in medicine
at the College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1860. At the outbreak of the
Civil War he promptly entered the Army and was captured while caring for
his wounded at Bull Run. He soon was permitted to escape and after a
varied and always creditable record of service during the remainder of
the War and thereafter with the scattered detachments of the Regular
Army, mostly in the far west, he had his first experience with yellow
fever in 1873 at Fort Barrances, near Pensacola, Florida. Again in
1874 and 1875 it reappeared and was the object of careful study, but
not until the latter year did he suffer an attack. He became thereafter
a leading authority on this disease and in 1879 was detailed for duty
with the Havana Yellow Fever Commission of our first and only National
Board of Health. From this time he became a leader in the newly develop-
ing science of bacteriology. In 1887 he visited Rio de Janeiro to in-
vestigate the claims of Dr. Freire to have discovered the causative agent
of yellow fever and later went to Mexico to look into a like claim of Dr.
Carmona de Valle, and was able in each case to make a negative finding.
In 1889 he was in Havana studying the organism for which Dr. Carlos Finlay
made like claims, to which he also gave the quietus with cold and logical
precision. [unclear] But Dr. Finlay's claim to fame did not rest solely
on his micrococcus tetragenus febris flavae and we shall hear from him
again later in our story. In 1893 hisSternberg's standing as a scientist was sufficient
to cause his selection as Surgeon General of the Army, and he immediately
did two things of far reaching importance. One was to establish the Army
Medical School for the advanced training of young medical officers. The
other was to wed genius to opportunity by bringing Walter Reed to Baltimore
for a period of study in the pathological hospitallaboratory of the Johns Hopkins
Hospital. He was also able, as the Chief of the Medical Corps, to infuse
into it a new spirit of professional enthusiasm and scientific ardor which
was later to bear good fruit. The Spanish War was for him a period of
-2-
heartbreaking struggle against the narrow and shortsighted spirit which
dominated the War Department. Of the $50,000,000 placed at the disposi-
tion of the President for the national defense, not a cent was given to
the pitifully small and ill equipped Medical Department, and in the law
raising a Volunteer Army no enlisted men were provided for the medical
service except a few regimental hospital stewards. As the War Department
was the adviser both of the President and of Congress as to the needs of
its branches, it must bear the responsibility for those sins of omission.
In 1900 he made his final and greatest contribution to the study of yellow
fever by sending Walter Reed to Cuba at the head of a group of three as-
sistants, Carroll, Lazear and Agramonte, primarily to investigate the claims
of the bacillus icteriodes of Sanarelli and those of his own bacillus x
to be the causative organism of that disease. They had, however, very broad
instructions from the Surgeon General authorizing the study of other tropical
diseases. The Hon. Elihu Root wrote of him, after his death, “The Medical
Corps accomplished what it did largely because the man at the top was a
pioneer in bacteriology, an advanced worker in preventive medicine and had
the enthusiasm and devotion through which science wins victories.” Here
we must leave this fine old scientist, who retired two years later, stand-
ing, as our author says, like Moses on Nebo, to see another enter the Promised
Land, after a lifetime of brave and earnest but fruitless effort, to learn the
secret of the Sphinx of Yellow Fever. Although he was as Koch said, the
“father of American bacteriology”, it cannot be said that his efforts had
contributed aught to solve this particular problem, except in the way of
clearing the field of false claimants. Scientific justice will incline to
give his place among the great four rather to Dr. Carlos Finlay of Havana,
who had also given twenty years of persistent study and experiment to this
-3-
facinating and elusive quest and who, though he did not have the disci-
plined scientific mind and technical skill and training in laboratory
technique of Sternberg, yet by a combination of epidemiological reason-
ing and what Gorgas called “scientific clairvoyance”, had reached the
right door, but lacked the scientific skill to open it and convince a
doubting world. It would appear, also, that though General Sternberg's
part in the sending of Reed's Commission to Cuba was an essential step,
so was the cordial support given by General Wood, both pecuniary and
moral, including, of course, his sharing the responsibility for the ex-
periments which were made at the risk of human lives. Fortunately, no
lives were lost in Reed's experiments, if we except the accidental in-
fection of Lazear, but in the later series conducted by Guiteras and
Gorgas, three patients lost their lives in one week, one of them a train-
ed nurse. This put an end to further experimental infections and for-
tunately Reed's series was so complete in the care with which all condi-
tions were covered, that there was no necessity for further jeopardy of
human lives. ThisTo discover the secret how yellow fever was transmitted and how it could be prevented was reserved by fate for Walter Reed, who combined the
scientific training of [unclear]Sternberg with the scientific imagination of [unclear] Finlay,
and whose ability as an epidemiologist had just been brilliantly manifest-
ed in the great study with Vaughan and Shakespeare of the typhoid fever
epidemics which swept through the Volunteer Camps of 1898.

Walter Reed was born in Gloucester County, Va., September 13, 1851.
His father was a Methodist minister, and in his education he shared the
financial limitations of the generation which grew up in the South during
the lean years which followed the Civil War. But what was lacking in oppor-
tunity was made up in real and industry, and he graduated in medicine at
the University of Virginia at the age of eighteen, when most young men are
-4-
preparing to begin a college course. His hospital courses were taken in
New York and he entered the Army in 1875 attracted, it seems, by the de-
sire for an assured income which would enable him to marry. For eighteen
years he followed the nomadic life and vicissitudes of the Army, most of
it at isolated frontier posts, without any chilling of his scientific ardor
or discouragement of his professional zeal by these unstimulating surround-
ings until at length opportunity rewarded patient waiting and an assignment
to duty in Baltimore for a year placed the resources of a laboratory within
his reach. No man ever made better use of a year, and when a change of
station to Dakota came, he was well grounded in pathology and bacteriology.
Two years later came his assignment as Curator of the Army Medical Museum
in Washington and promotion to the grade of Major, and he followed the Army
life no more, but enjoyed the contacts and opportunities of scientific as-
sociations in Washington and Baltimore. We have already seen how the oppor-
tunity came in 1900 which carried him to Havana at the head of the board
now generally known as the Yellow Fever Commission. When Reed discussed
with his Chief the objectives of the Commission and mentioned Finlay's
mosquito theory as a possible one, General Sternberg replied, “You may
do it if you want to, but there is nothing in it”. The claims of the
latest protendants for the evil fame of being the causative agent Bacillus
icteroides andof Sanarelli and Sternberg's Bacillus x were soon disposed of
by the Commission after its arrival in Havana. In fact, most of the work
had been already done by Agramonte, who had worked on these organisms in
Reed's laboratory in 1898 and who was now in Cuba.

Three lines of research were now considered by the Commission -
a study of the bacterial flora of the intestine in this disease and its
comparison with the normal flora, studies of cultures from the blood and
-5-
various organs, and Finlay's mosquito theory.
Reed decided to take up the last first. His attention had been attracted
to an observation made by Dr. Henry R. Carter in 1898 and published with-
out interpretation, which was that when a case of yellow fever occurs in
an isolated farm house, secondary cases do not occur for two to three weeks
but susceptible individuals who then visit the house fall sick in the usual
period of incubation, less than seven days. In talking to the writer soon
after his arrival in Cuba, Reed mentioned this observation and asked what
it meant. Upon receiving an admission of ignorance, he said, with raised
forefinger, “Don't you see that the difference between the two periods must
represent the time passed in the body of some intermediate host? What
are the common biting insects in the South [unclear] , the bed bug, the flea and the
mosquito. Now the bed bug and the flea are common in the mountains of the
South, where yellow fever never spreads. The disease also disappears when
frost comes, though it does not affect these insects. So it is some southern
genus of mosquito that we must suspect”. So Reed determined to begin work
with the common house mosquito of Havana, then called Culex faciatus, but
later named Stegomyia fasciata. He was given by Dr. Finlay a saucer on the
side of which were some of the minute eggs of this insect which could be
hatched into larvae by simply putting water in the saucer. Dr. Finlay
told him that this was the insect used in his experiments and he believed
it to be the carrier of yellow fever. Dr. Finlay believed that he had, in
a few cases, transmitted the disease by their agency, but the period of
incubation was far longer than that commonly accepted for yellow fever,
and as the subjects of experiment had not been protected from other sources
of infection, these experiments were not accepted as a demonstration of
his claims. Dr. Lazear was in charge of the propagation and infection of
the mosquitos, a difficult task, since a successful laboratory technique
-6-
for their propagation, infection, feeding and preservation had to be
developed. The first experiments, which were made on Lazear, Carroll,
and Dr. Pinto, Volunteer Army Surgeon,of the Army and others, were made in pro-
found secrecy and were all discouraging failures. These happened while
Reed was absent, having been called to Washington to arrange for the
publication of the Report of the Commission on Typhoid Fever in Military
Camps.

On the morning of August 31,1900, Lazear was at the hospital
of Camp Columbia, the camp being then in quarantine against the neighbor-
ing infected towns of Marianao and Havana. He went into the ward with
several mosquitos in test tubes and said, “Who will feed my mosquitos”.
A private of the 7th Cavalry, in hospital for some minor ailment, offered
his arm and was bitten. Those mosquitos had been infected and had previous-
ly bitten Carroll. On that very day Carroll came down with a severe case
which nearly cost him his life, and some days later the Cavalryman, known
in the reports as XY, came down with a mild but well marked case. Great
was the wonder at the hospital as to where he got his infection, for he
had not left the camp and his obliging donation of blood to Lazear's
mosquitos was not thought of by any one else as having any connection with
the case. Lazear said nothing but wrote to Reed that he felt like a gambler
who had the joker up his sleeve. A searching analysis of his notes reveal-
ed the cause of the previous failures in the fact that the female mosquito,
after having bitten a case of yellow fever, is not able to transmit the
infection until after twelve days - the so called period of extrinsic in-
cubation. In writing the report of this crucial case, Reed was in an
amusing dilemma. It was necessary to make it quite clear that the subject
was protected from every other possible source of infection and was sur-
rounded by numerous controls who lived under like conditions, except only
-7-
that of not having been bitten. Yet it was important not to betray the
secret that a member of the Commission had introduced the dreaded in-
fection into a closely quarantined camp where were living 1,300 American
soldiers, as this would have caused a great row and disciplinary action by the military authorities. So the name of this important contributor to the advancement
of science has never been published. Meanwhile the brave and gifted
Lazear had, while feeding mosquitos on cases of yellow fever at Las
Animas Hospital in Havana, been bitten by a mosquito which came from
a dark corner of the ward. He permitted it to fill itself on his hand
and noted it as an additional experiment. In due time he was taken down
with virulent yellow fever and a week later he died.

Reed, on October 13th made a flying trip to the United States
to read his preliminary note on the etiology of yellow fever before the
American Public Health Association and to consult his Chief, General
Sternberg, as to further procedures. On the 12th of October, the day
before he sailed, he went, accompanied by the writer, to see General Wood
and to ask his assistance in the larger task which was to come. It was
an experience never to be forgotten to see these two men, both great but
differing so greatly, Wood massive in frame and unmoved in expression,
Reed tall, slender, keen and emotional, as they stood together in the
deep embrasure of a window of the palace looking out on the Plaza des Armas.
Reed, with that earnest and persuasive eloquence of which he was a master,
described the experiments and the results which would flow from them and
then said, “General Wood, will you give me the money and the authority
necessary to continue these experiments”? Promptly came the reply of the
Military Governor, “I will give you $10,000- and if that is not enough,
I will give you $10,000 more”.

Although the fact that yellow fever could be conveyed by mos-
quitos was now demonstrated, much still remained to be done. The belief
-8-
was universal that the infection could be carried by clothing and other
inanimate objects, known by the general term fomites. The general re-
action at this time was expressed by Gorgas, that the mosquito was not
the only way. Therefore Reed built a camp called after Lazear, a mile
from any habitation, in with two separate buildings divided by a little valley.
One was clean and new and everything about it was carefully disinfected.
Yet it would be an infected house because infected mosquitos were placed
in it. The other contained every filthy article taken from cases of yel-
low fever which might possibly carry infection, the soiled sheets and gar-
ments on which they had died, soiled with black vomit and dejecta, a place
of sights and odors which demanded steady nerves and a strong stomach even
to enter. Yet American soldiers were found and an Army doctor, Robert P. Cooke, to live
in this place of horrors for twenty days, but no case of infection ever
came from it. From the other house, however, came case after case of
non-immunes who came down after a bite from the infected Stegomyia. The
experiments were so ably devised, each with its controls, to elucidate
a definite fact, that they stand as a model of exact scientific method.
When a similar Commission was formed in the A.E.F. in 1918 to investigate
the etiology of trench fever, it looked up and followed closely the pro-
cedures of Reed at Camp Lazear.

The riddle of the Sphinx was solved. Gone was the costly ritual
of disinfections of merchandise and personal property, the fear of contact
with one's neighbors and the shotgun quarantines. Gone was the fighting
in the dark against an invisible and unknown enemy. The deductions as to
the future methods of warfare were simple and clear and were adopted as soon
as indicated by him. In fact, they were immediately put into operation at
the military posts and in the Sanitary Department of Havana under its since
-9-
famous sanitary officer, Major W. C. Gorgas. The result was the practical
abolition of yellow fever in Havana in the summer of 1901 and its entire
extinction in that city and throughout the island in 1902. This happy re-
sult Reed lived to see and also to enjoy the beginning of popular recog-
nition in degrees from Harvard and the University of Michigan. He died
as the result of after an operation for appendicitis in Washington, November 22, 1902.
His monument in Arlington bears an inscription quoted from President Eliot's
citation when he conferred on him the honorary degree of A.M. at Harvard,
“He gave to man control over that dreadful scourge, Yellow Fever”.

Of great interest and value are the sketches of Reed's assistants,
Carroll, Lazear and Agramonte, given in this volume, and it is regretted that
the limits of a newspaper article do not permit of a review of them. The
tragic death of Lazear has already been noted. Dr. Carroll was, in recog-
nition of this work, commissioned in the Medical Corps and raised to the
grade of Major. He died in Washington, September 16, 1907. The government
has given to the widows of Reed, Carroll and Lazear modest pensions which
are now quite inadequate for their support. For the fourth and only sur-
viving member of the Commission there has never been any reward or official
recognition of his services, and this opportunity will not be lost to join
Dr. Kelly in reminding the American people of their obligation to Dr.
Aristides Agramonte, in the hope that he may, some day, receive from Congress
some appropriate reward. Dr. Agramonte was born in Puerto Principe, Cuba,
June 3, 1868. His father was the distinguished Cuban patriot, General Eduardo
Agramonte, who fell bravely in battle for his country. Dr. Agramonte re-
ceived his education in New York and his degree in Medicine from the College
of Physicians & Surgeons of that city. In May 1898 he entered the military
service and went to Santiago in July and to Havana in December of that year,
-10-
when he was engaged in the study of yellow fever. There he was when
Reed's Commission was organized. In addition to the work with the Com-
mission, he was in charge of the Army Laboratory of Cuba, which post he
retained until the withdrawal of the Military Government in 1902, when
he remained in Cuba as a professor of the Medical Faculty of the University of
Havana. When a Reform Cabinet was appointed by the Cuban Government in
June of last year, he was selected for the Secretaryship of Sanitation
and Charities. His strong, independent character and straightforward
honesty were not qualities conducive to long political life under pres-
ent conditions in Cuba, and before the end of the year he resigned to
return to his professorial duties.

The interesting career of Surgeon General Gorgas is given in
outline in the last chapter, which has the appropriate heading, “Reed's
Work Made Effective”. William C. Gorgas was born October 3,1854 in
Mobile, Ala. His father was a distinguished and able man, a West Point
graduate, who took the southern side in the Civil War and became Chief
of Ordnance in the Confederate War Department. As the Confederacy lacked
the skilled workmen and machinery and many of the raw materials for making
ordnance, and such arms as they had were of every known calibre and make,
the heartbreaking difficulties of his task can be imagined. His energy
and resourcefulness in overcoming them were such that the Confederate sol-
diers, although lacking in nearly every necessity of life, seemed always
sufficiently supplied with arms and ammunition to make their proximity
highly dangerous to their adversaries. After the war he became President
of the University of the South at Sewance, where his distinguished son
received his education. The latter graduated in Medicine at Bellevue
College, New York, and then entered the Medical Corps of the Army.
-11-
Soon after, while stationed at Fort Brown, Texas, he made the acquaintance
of Yellow Jack and acquired immunity from and interest in that disease by
experiencing an attack. The Spanish War found him at Fort Barrancas, Fla.,
and being an immune and an authority on yellow fever, he was sent to Havana
for duty soon after the Americans took control. There he worked bravely
and hopefully but without any particular success as far as the control of
yellow fever was concerned until the work of the Reed Commission made suc-
cess possible. Just at this time, in April 1900, on the eve of his first
great success, he was relieved from duty in Havana and ordered to Santiago,
and it is interesting to speculate as to what would have been the effect
on his future career if this order had been carried out. He was fortunate
enough, however, to get it revoked through the assistance of General Fitzhugh
Lee and General Leonard Wood. Our author's statement that Gorgas achieved
the remarkable success of cleaning up the Island is not, however, entirely
accurate as his sphere of activity never, at any time, extended beyond the
municipal limits of the City of Havana. The story of Gorgas's fine work in
Panama is told briefly but effectively by our author and for a fuller ac-
count the reader is referred to Gorgas's own book, “Sanitation in Panama”.
With the triumphal results the American people are well acquainted, but of
the difficulties which he encountered, much is still unwritten history.
Our author tells how the recall of Gorgas was requested by the Governor
and Chief Engineer in 1905 because they did not believe that mosquitos
carried yellow fever and malaria, but the Commission was recalled instead.
It is also true that on another occasion the Secretary of War had been
persuaded that it was necessary to relieve him, but this was prevented by
the valiant support of Gorgas by Surgeon General O'Reilly. Thus, a second
-12-
time was he saved to fame by the loyalty of his friends. In the end his
patience, his suavity, his unshakeable pertinacity conquered all obstacles,
human, insect and inanimate. He returned home the most widely known of
American physicians and became in 1914 the Chief of his Corps, to which
were added promotion, honors, degrees, decorations and the thanks of Congress.
When he died in London, July 4,1921, his funeral services were held in
Westminster Abbey.

The chapter in this book which is perhaps the most moving and the
fullest of human interest is the tenth entitled “The Value of Dr. Reed's
Work to the World”. He tells of the great epidemics which have ravaged
the United States and shows how in former days it spread far to the north
of its sub-tropical home. It visited Boston as early as 1691 - New York
experienced 14 epidemics and Philadelphia 18 prior to the middle of the
last century, including the dreadful visitation of 1793, when one-tenth of
the population perished. But to the North yellow fever has been an infre-
quent and of recent years a rare visitor. For the South, however, who can
estimate the retarding influence to its development of the 90 visitations
in two centuries, by the loss of valuable lives, the disturbance of trade
and business, the quarantines and the repulsion of desirable immigrants?
The epidemic of 1878 is estimated to have cost the country more than
$15,000,000 in money, but no statistician can estimate the cost in panic
fears in disrupted homes and in the tears of widows and orphans. From all
these, the work of Reed's Commission in one short year, with the practical
applications of its findings, has delivered us.

We shall end this review with the quotation from the book of
Esther, which Dr. Kelly has placed at the head of this chapter,
-13-
“And the king said, What honour and dignity hath been done to Mordecai
for this? Then said the king's servants that ministered to him, There
is nothing done for him”.

Walter Reed left no fortune and his widow receives from this
great government an annuity insufficient for her support. This is also
true of the widows of Carroll and Lazear.
